newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Siemens, Mosel in $1.7 bln deal.
newsitem.headline: Siemens, Mosel in $1.7 bln deal.

text.p: Taiwan's Mosel Vitalic Inc said on Friday it will formally sign a contract with German electronics giant Siemens AG on November 7 to set up a US$1.7 billion venture to produce advanced dynamic random access memory, or DRAM, chips in Taiwan.
Siemens in late September announced a decision to form a venture with Mosel, but mentioned few details.
"In fact, we already have signed the deal, but a formal signing ceremony with Siemens will be held on November 7," Mosel vice-president William Chen told Reuters.
The new venture, ProMOS Technologies Inc, will be in Hsinchu, outside Taipei. Mosel will hold 62 percent and Siemens 38 percent.
The venture will operate a chip factory already being constructed by Mosel and set up a joint research and development centre for DRAMs, Chen said.
The venture will produce 64 megabit and 256 megabit DRAMs, he said.

Both sides will invest $1.7 billion in two stages, with the first stage -- costing $1 billion -- expected to start production in mid-1997, and the second stage -- costing $700 million -- seen to begin production in late 1998, Chen said.
The venture's monthly production capacity will reach 20,000 eight-inch wafers of DRAMs by the end of 1997, and 40,000 wafers by end-1998, Chen said.

"Despite the recent oversupply situation in the semiconductor industry, keeping on expansion is our long-term development strategy," Chen said. Mosel is one of the island's leading DRAM chip makers. -- Taipei Newsroom (5080815)
